conclusion: Understanding the relationship between volume, temperature, and pressure of an ideal gas.
Introduction of the ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
Since the mass of the gas is constant, n is constant.
Point A: P_A = P₀, T_A = T₀, V_A = V₀.
Point B is directly above point A, line AB is vertical, meaning volume is constant from A to B.
From A to B, volume remains V₀, temperature increases to T_B.
Point B is at V = 2V₀ and T = T₀.
There might be a misunderstanding in the description of point B.
Line segment AB is parallel to the V axis, meaning constant V.
Assuming horizontal axis is T, vertical axis is V, point A at (T₀, V₀), point B at (T_B, 2V₀).
Extension of BC passes through the origin.
Need to find the temperature at state C.
From A to B: Volume increases from V₀ to 2V₀, temperature remains T₀.
Using ideal gas law: P_B = P₀ / 2.
Pressure decreases to half from A to B.
From B to C: Volume decreases from 2V₀ to V_C, temperature increases from T₀ to T_C.
Slope of OC is the same as slope of BC.
Set slopes equal: V_C / T_C = (V_C - 2V₀)/(T_C - T₀).
